verses.text: Praise the LORD! Give thanks to the LORD, for he is good; his steadfast love endures forever.
verses.comment: This opening sets the praise for God's eternal mercy, a common theme throughout the Psalms. 'Steadfast love' (Heb: hesed) often points to God's covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: Who can speak of the mighty acts of the LORD, or declare all his praise?
verses.comment: God's deeds and glory surpass human comprehension, highlighting our need to worship in humility before his grandeur.

verses.text: Blessed are those who keep justice, and do righteousness at all times.
verses.comment: Consistent pursuit of justice and righteousness brings blessing; this echoes the call to holiness as a response to God's mercy.

verses.text: Remember me, LORD, with the favor you show to your people; come to me with your salvation,
verses.comment: The psalmist requests personal inclusion in God's redemptive work, illustrating both individual and communal aspects of salvation.

verses.text: so I may see the good of your chosen ones, rejoice in your nation's joy, and boast with your inheritance.
verses.comment: God’s people (Israel) are described as 'chosen' and 'inheritance', terms later retaken by the Church, connecting the Old Testament community to those who share in the promises through Christ (1 Peter 2:9).

verses.text: We have sinned, just like our ancestors; we have done wrong and acted wickedly.
verses.comment: Notice the confession of communal sin, showing solidarity in repentance, a model for prayers of contrition and reconciliation.

verses.text: Our fathers, in Egypt, did not grasp your wonders; they did not remember your many mercies, but rebelled by the sea, at the Red Sea.
verses.comment: Israel’s forgetfulness and rebellion at the Red Sea remind us of the importance of remembering God’s saving works.

verses.text: Yet he saved them for his name’s sake, to make known his mighty power.
verses.comment: God’s deliverance is for the sake of his own name, showing that salvation is God-initiated and for his glory.

verses.text: He rebuked the Red Sea, and it dried up; and he led them through the depths as through a desert.
verses.comment: A recounting of the Exodus, showing God’s power over creation and affirming the miraculous nature of salvation history.

verses.text: He saved them from the hand of the one who hated them, and redeemed them from the enemy.
verses.comment: ‘Redeemed’ (Heb: ga’al) indicates liberation through sacrifice—a theme that foreshadows Christ’s own redemptive work.

verses.text: The waters covered their foes; not one of them was left.
verses.comment: The complete destruction of Egypt’s army points to God’s total victory over evil; a spiritual battle paralleled in Christ’s victory over sin and death.

verses.text: Then they believed his words; they sang his praise.
verses.comment: Faith and praise follow deliverance, yet as the psalm continues, this faith proves fragile, warning us against forgetting God.

verses.text: But they quickly forgot his works; they did not wait for his counsel.
verses.comment: Impatience and forgetfulness lead to sin; reliance on God’s guidance is essential for perseverance in faith.

verses.text: They craved intensely in the wilderness and tested God in the desert.
verses.comment: Testing God recalls Israel’s lack of trust; this theme is spiritually tied to temptations faced by Christ (Matt. 4:1–11).

verses.text: So he gave them what they asked for, but sent leanness into their souls.
verses.comment: Earthly desires granted without spiritual benefit bring spiritual barrenness, teaching the importance of seeking God’s will above our own.

verses.text: They grew envious of Moses in the camp, and of Aaron, the LORD’s holy one.
verses.comment: Rebellion against God’s appointed leaders foreshadows the honor due to those chosen to guide God’s people—a theme continuing in the Church’s hierarchical structure.

verses.text: The earth opened up and swallowed Dathan, and covered the company of Abiram.
verses.comment: God’s judgment against open rebellion exemplifies the seriousness of rejecting divinely instituted order.

verses.text: Fire blazed among their company; a flame consumed the wicked.
verses.comment: Divine judgment by fire is a sign of God's holiness and justice, echoing later imagery of purification and judgment.

verses.text: They made a calf at Horeb and worshiped a metal image.
verses.comment: Idolatry at Sinai stands as the classic example of spiritual infidelity; the worship of images is repeatedly condemned as a violation of direct communion with the true God.

verses.text: They exchanged their glory for the image of an ox that eats grass.
verses.comment: Turning from divine glory to lifeless idols foreshadows Paul’s later condemnation of idolatry (Romans 1:23).

verses.text: They forgot God, their Savior, who had done great things in Egypt,
verses.comment: Forgetting God after salvation points to the need for continuous remembrance through liturgical and sacramental life.

verses.text: wonders in the land of Ham, and awesome deeds by the Red Sea.
verses.comment: God’s power shown in Egypt is recalled as evidence for his saving presence.

verses.text: So he said he would destroy them, but Moses, his chosen one, stood in the breach before him, to turn away his wrath from destroying them.
verses.comment: Moses acts as a mediator, pleading for the people—a prefiguration of Christ’s unique mediatorship (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: Then they despised the pleasant land; they did not believe his promise.
verses.comment: Refusal to enter the promised land shows the consequences of unbelief; God’s promises call for trust above obstacles.

verses.text: They grumbled in their tents, and did not obey the voice of the LORD.
verses.comment: Persistent grumbling reflects hearts hardened against God’s commands—a warning against spiritual complacency.

verses.text: So he lifted his hand and swore to make them fall in the wilderness,
verses.comment: God’s oath seals the judgment for unbelief, showing the seriousness of breaking covenant.

verses.text: and to scatter their offspring among the nations, and disperse them in the lands.
verses.comment: Prophecy of dispersion is fulfilled in the Exile, yet the hope of restoration runs through the biblical narrative.

verses.text: They joined themselves to Baal of Peor, and ate sacrifices offered to lifeless gods.
verses.comment: Eating idol sacrifices highlights the importance of right worship and echoes Paul’s warnings about idolatry (1 Cor. 10:21).

verses.text: They provoked the LORD with their deeds, so that a plague broke out among them.
verses.comment: Direct consequences followed the spiritual transgressions, underscoring the reality of divine justice and its connection to human freedom.

verses.text: But Phinehas stood up and intervened, and the plague was stopped.
verses.comment: Intercession by a righteous person averts God’s wrath; Phinehas prefigures righteous mediators, culminating in Christ.

verses.text: And that was counted to him as righteousness for all generations forever.
verses.comment: Righteous acts are remembered eternally, linking faith and works in God’s plan.

verses.text: They angered him at the waters of Meribah, and it went poorly for Moses because of them;
verses.comment: Even the leader Moses suffered for the people’s rebellion; leadership is a holy responsibility requiring trust in God.

verses.text: for they made his spirit bitter, so that he spoke rashly with his lips.
verses.comment: Sin affects even the greatest of God’s servants; Moses’ failure reflects the universal human need for grace.

verses.text: They did not destroy the peoples as the LORD had commanded them,
verses.comment: Failure to obey leads to spiritual compromise; God’s commands are meant to preserve holiness among his people.

verses.text: but mixed themselves among the nations and learned their practices.
verses.comment: Mixing with other nations led to idolatry and moral decline, a warning about assimilating worldly values.

verses.text: They served their idols, which became a snare to them.
verses.comment: Idols are repeatedly described as traps, keeping people from true worship and relationship with God.

verses.text: They sacrificed their sons and daughters to demons,
verses.comment: The horror of child sacrifice shows the depths of human rebellion when rejecting God—a grave sin with deep social and spiritual consequences.

verses.text: and they poured out innocent blood—the blood of their sons and daughters whom they sacrificed to the idols of Canaan—and the land was polluted with blood.
verses.comment: The crime of bloodshed brings defilement and necessitates purification, echoing later themes of atonement and redemption.

verses.text: So they became unclean by their deeds and prostituted themselves by what they did.
verses.comment: Spiritual and moral impurity is likened to infidelity, using strong covenant language found throughout the prophets.

verses.text: Then the LORD’s anger was kindled against his people, and he abhorred his inheritance.
verses.comment: God’s response highlights both justice and the seriousness of sin, yet as the narrative continues, mercy will prevail.

verses.text: He gave them into the hand of the nations, and those who hated them ruled over them.
verses.comment: God’s people suffer exile and persecution due to their unfaithfulness, yet these sufferings become a means for repentance and eventual restoration.

verses.text: Their enemies oppressed them, and they were subjected under their hand.
verses.comment: Oppression under enemies is described as just consequence, yet opens the door for future deliverance.

verses.text: Many times he delivered them, but they were stubborn in their plans and sank lower in their guilt.
verses.comment: God’s mercy is persistent, but human stubbornness leads repeatedly to downfall; true conversion remains the needed response.

verses.text: Even so, he saw their distress when he heard their cry;
verses.comment: Despite their sin, God is always attentive to repentance and will answer the cry of his people.

verses.text: and he remembered his covenant for them, and relented according to the abundance of his steadfast love.
verses.comment: God’s mercy flows from his covenant promises; steadfast love anchors hope for forgiveness and restoration.

verses.text: He made them pitied by all who held them captive.
verses.comment: Divine favor softens the hearts of captors, showing God’s providence at work even in exile.

verses.text: Save us, LORD our God, and gather us from among the nations, that we may give thanks to your holy name and glory in your praise.
verses.comment: The prayer for gathering points both to the return of Israel, and spiritually, to God’s promise to unite people from all nations in praise—hinting at the universality of God's plan.

verses.text: Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, from everlasting to everlasting! Let all the people say, Amen! Praise the LORD!
verses.comment: Doxology closes the psalm in communal worship; the repeated 'Amen' affirms the faithful response and forms the liturgical ending echoed in Christian worship traditions.
